comments.commentBody: Sociopathic is too daring, and unfair, in my opinion.   Sociopaths have no conscience—the same thing as a non-violent psychopath like the Bernie Madoffs of the world.  Perhaps you meant pathological or obsessive, or even narcissistic would fit.  Not all child or teen prodigies have lives that end in tragedy; but some do.  When people are extremely hardworking, dedicated, passionate, and immensely successful, many people prefer the term Brilliant.  I don't really care that much about Taylor Swift, and to me, her music is not much more sophisticated than bubble gum, but I hope you're wrong nonetheless.

Participation by eligible voters was down below 38 percent, and looked to be holding there, making this one of the lowest participation rates since ww2, in 1942. The party faithful, and those with axes to grind are the ones who beat feet to the polls. Reagan, Clinton, Bush all dealt with the inevitable over exposure but with Obama, they've been hamnering home the "other" theme of his Presidency, secret Imam traitor seeking reparations for slavery by punishing innocent whites and so forth. Say it over and over, and now the tv nation of Fox delivers on a campaign propaganda promise? What a surprise for the nation.
But you can't govern with "Obama evil..." utterances, and when America sees this crew in action with more dribble-down on you voodoo economics that hasn't worked since Reagan brought it to town, anti women initiatives and tax breaks for the rich. Attacks on social security. Yeah, see you in 2016. The American public will once again be fed up with Tea Party nonsense like Ryan trying to gut Medicare with a voucher give away to health care insurance executives, that left seniors wirh a 6,000 bill at year's end. Great bunch. Five minutes in power and see what they try....That's why they'll never, EVER win the national election again. They know it. That's why poll taxes are back with voter id, to suppress votes, and Cirizens United 2.0, 3.0 and 4.0 to dump 20 million a day in outside money into Senate race.
They're soooo bad, tho, they can never win the W.H. again.

The Dems are getting what they deserve. They didn't show up to vote - They ran away from the President - They ran away from their successes. They pestered the faithful with multiple pleas for $$ daily - every day - so much so that it became annoying and made me want to turn off anything they had to say.

Unfortunately, folks don't show up to vote in the midterms - and in doing so abdicate control of state houses and congress which greatly affects their lives. Don't blame voter id laws - its not like no one knew this was happening - it should have motivated people to get valid id and go to the polls in droves. Sad, but the folks who will suffer most from the avowed Republican policies as the same ones who couldn't get to the polls or who voted Republican because of the demonization of the President and his policies. Go figure. As for me - I'll mostly likely do very well under the Republican policies - or at least won't be affected in the short term - its just that their view of society where each man is for himself is not one in which I want my children to grow up in - I believe Jesus was right - what you do to the least of my brothers - that you do unto me.

While I know personally some would-be voters who were stymied by ID laws, I have to admit - much to my chagrin at my fellow citizens - that turnout is an enormous problem. This midterm electorate was even more white and older than in 2010. Given that the older white voters are headed toward being an even smaller part of the overall electorate in time, it's doubly frustrating - how can any politician, regardless of party, claim a "mandate" or affirmation of his/her policies when so few voters actually show up?

Until a wider, more diverse population, encompassing all of the races, ethnicities, socioeconomic statuses, education levels, ages, etc. shows up not just for presidential elections but also in midterms, this cycle will continue.

Don't get me wrong - I oppose the voter ID laws that so many GOP law makers have grown enamored with in recent years. But it also makes me feel even *more* strongly that those of us who have no barriers to voting should be doing so, every single election. If we truly want representative government, we need to exercise our right to choose the representative.

I'd be curious if voter ID had anything to do with this years election. The GOP was clearly out in full force and the Democrats weren't. Or perhaps it was the independent aka non-affiliated voters that tilted the scales in this election. Comparing 2010's numbers with this year would be helpful in this discussion.

And yet Republicans won a majority of seats in the Senate. Are you arguing that they are out of touch with the electorate? People voted for them. So perhaps the electorate yearns for the "Gilded Age"? Or maybe they want more emphasis on freedom and less on the nanny state. Votes aren't for sale in this country, Team Blue outspent Team Red in Iowa and Colorado but still lost.

" Team Blue outspent Team Red in Iowa and Colorado but still lost."

This does not count dark money.

There's plenty of blame to go around for the sorry state of our political system, but most of the blame goes to the Republicans, who have pursued a "scorched earth" policy in Congress and hamstrung the ability of the President or anyone to get things done. They have become the party of "no" in no uncertain terms. Accusing the Democrats of being too liberal, or progressive if you will, doesn't ring true; the great age of Democratic liberalism was the 1930's through 1960's, when their accomplishments were stuff that we can only dream about today. In that era (which was certainly not trouble-free), labor unions were the chief supporters of Democratic liberalism, but today's relegation of what's left of the unions to the sidelines has left the Democrats dependent to a much larger extent on Big Money. So if anything, Democrats have been forced further to the right.

In that earlier era, mainstream Republicans like Eisenhower were about as liberal as today's Democrats, but today's Republicans seem to yearn to return to the "Gilded Age" of the late 19th Century, when J.P. Morgan and the rest of the Four Hundred ran the country, people (including children) worked 14-hour days, living conditions for many were squalid, and disease was rampant.

So yes, our democracy is in trouble, but that's the way Republicans seem to want it. They did what they could to suppress votes in some states and buy elections in others. They want government of, by, and for the rich, not for the rest of us.
Meredith - throw your hat in the ring. It's a free country. What's stopping you?

What do you mean "will leave running for office..." ?
It would be more accurate to say, "has left running for office".
Although this may be how it has almost always been.

Students are turning not to politics but to social enterprise, to nonprofits, to advocacy, to business?

So who’s left to do our lawmaking then? This will leave running for office to the most dishonest, exploitive manipulators, seeking an easy path to wealth. Just get on the right committees and form a combo with business and big donors. Call any pushback interference in political free speech. Then set up tax laws so the wealth transfer up continues. Responsibility to society is now called govt intrusion into private profit.

About half the congress is said to be millionaires. It’s easy money since their staffs do most of the work, the donors’ and public relations people write their scripts, and media favorites seeking access do their interviews. Then congress recesses and takes vacations. All with gold plated health care and retirement and jobs in business awaiting them. Is this an exaggeration, brought on by a bad mood after the election, Mr. Kristof?

And why would you want to murder an innocent, and extremely intelligent beings such as elephants or sharks? Money or not our first responsibility is to see the whole picture before we make a decision.
When you have money you get what you want.  Simple as that.

Ivory is a status symbol in China much like a fur coat was a status symbol in my country once. It took very creative people to come up with brilliant advertising to make fur coats UNCOOL and when they did- the demand disappeared. We need help from creative people, designers and luxury brands to make Ivory totally uncool...we need to stop the demand

All the Chinese should be ashamed and embarrassed to be the number one buyer of ivory! Learn to conserve and protect these beautiful animals! Shame on you who support this awful illegal trade. If the persistent did allow this to occur he should be jailed, or executed like they do in China!

I think some forms of national referendum, like many of those in the states, should be available to the general public across the USA. Some issues which the majority of the American public agree on find obstacles in the Congress, like the minimal wage, gun control and contraception issues.

Congress responds only to the 1% big donors, individuals and corporations, they answer only to these special interest groups with big money and not to the general public. National referendum would bypass the least trusted branch of the government.

The "nose" comment reminds me of the Woody Allen science fiction spoof, "Sleeper", in which the nose of a future society's leader is all that remains of him, growing in a Petri dish, awaiting the day when it can be cloned into the full human body it once was.
This begs the question, if a fully developed human can be cloned from nose cells, is the nose already a "person"?
Should "personhood" laws be amended to include cells ready for cloning? If I slice off a piece of living skin, keep it alive in a dish, ready for cloning, is it already a person? Do I thus have an identical twin?
She never said "this being" is not of "our species".

I heard an interesting narrative the other day about banning abortion (forced birth). Imagine that a father is shown to be the perfect donor for a child's ill-functioning kidneys and that the child will surely die w/o this donated kidney. Yet the father himself might not WANT to give up one of his 2 kidneys. He himself could die from the operation or later from a problem w/ his remaining kidney. Should all fathers be FORCED to give up an organ for the sake of their dying child?  I might add that birth control is definitely not perfect, so anyone who thinks banning abortions is ok as long as women can access  BC is uninformed at the least. I carefully and correctly followed the directions on 2 types of birth control prescribed by my doctors at two times when pregnancy would have proved a health threat yet ended up pregnant both times.

So "splain me this personhood thing. A product of sexual reproduction, from the moment a microscopic cell starts to divide, is a "person" with full rights and privileges accorded our species?

But wait - this speck of protoplasm requires a "host." I know that "science" is an evil hoax, but yes, the earth does circle the sun, and no, the earth is not flat.

A parasite is an organism that depends on getting its nourishment and protection from another organism. How do we reconcile the "rights" of the parasite and the host?
The host of course, is a fully-formed, adult,
sentient human, - almost always a female - curiously.

My foremothers taught me that "In this Democracy your rights end where my nose begins."

So whose "nose" prevails? Does a collection of cells - growing every day by the bounty of its "host" render the woman who harbors it to the status of a petri dish?

The most basic, fundamental, and irrefutable right of a human being is the right to its own body. "Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of happiness" begins and ends in this basic precept.

And guess what? Women are people too.

This is a good news story, and I am not a baseball fan, in fact am not interested in baseball at all.  Just when you think the US is going down the tubes, something like this happens - a Canadian/Pakistani Muslim teamed with a Jew to rescue the Dodgers.  I take it back:  it's not a good story, it's a great story.

"lost ervenue from a corporate rate reduction?"

Liberals often fail to understand how taxation works, so mistakenly believe that lower tax rates result in lost revenue. The opposite is true. With a lower rate, companies are more likely to bring cash home and foreign companies are more likely to locate operations here. Money flows to where its less expensive.

So, you eliminate the corporate tax, they repatriate their massive cash hoards, and presumably they'd use said hoards for stock buybacks (since the opportunities for productive private investment in a demand limited economy are limited).

So, stock prices jump, enriching large shareholders, corporate execs get even larger pay packages, and your average worker gets nothing.. well, except for even even an even weaker safety net and more broken and inadequate government services.

The old 'lower taxes == more money' con has had it's day; it doesn't work for anything aside from accelerating a race to the bottom for just about everyone but the top 1%.
Supply side standard response.  Disproven time and time again.  Look at Kansas for exhibit one.  Look at Kansas voters for the persistence of this zombie idea despite all evidence.

And what does the President agree to cut in return for the lost ervenue from a corporate rate reduction? Without closing any exisiting loopholes or  finding a new revenue source to replace that lost by the rate reduction, this just sounds like aiding and abetting the "starve the beast" approach of the Republicans to continue to hobble and destroy the government.
I like this guy.

I believe Obama administration and GOP can find common ground on Cuba.
I'm a long time Independent with a Mexican-American mother and ever since I visited the Republic of Cuba in 1999 as a tourist on the sly through the Bahamas I have dreamed of the day when relations, trade, and tourism would be restored. It would mean jobs for Southwest ports and airports, for farm products, and tour agencies. Yes, the Castro regime, hated by the right-wing Cuban-Americans and the GOP would survive, but guess what, so have the Chinese and Vietnamese regimes, countries with which we now have full diplomatic, travel and trade relations. Further, our US government can learn a lot from Cuba, such as universal health care, total elimination of homelessness and violent crimes, etc.

Scientella - If Obama starts vetoing then Rebubs will say he's the one all along who's been obstructing, and this will lead to more Repub victories in 2016. That's probably been their strategy all along.

Obama should, now with NOTHING to lose, finaly STOP COMPROMISING!

Give us what we voted for. Stonewall completely .VETO EVERYTHING.

If he doesnt he is a complete and utter washout. HE will stand by while they dismantle Obama care.

He should VETO the pipeline.

He dissapointed us by showing he was only interested in power, and his liberal platform was only to get elected. THAT is why too many Dems stayed at home.

NOW for teh history books President O. GIVE US WHAT WE VOTED FOR.

VETO EVERYTHNG!!!!

Why Eugene, I think I totally disagree with everything in your message, every word, even the articles, the conjunctions, and the punctuation marks. I am close to inclusion in the 1% and nothing I possess was tossed over a fence to me. I worked incredibly hard for it and intend to resist redistributionist efforts to take it away from me. You may have never considered this, but we red state Tea Party types are not without our wiles, talents, and even a type of low cunning.

Note that prior to the Affordable Care Act, when Repubs had congressional majorities and controlled the White House, they never did anything to reform the American health care system, expect enact health savings accounts.  These allow you to put a little money in an account that doesn't get taxed, oh wow, and you can spend it on your health care.  That was it.  Nothing about millions of uninsured, nothing about the fleecing we get from the system, nothing. That's the policy they represent.

The Elephant in the room is keep your paws off healthcare.  I'd be surprised if Repubs could amass such a following see, for if they can mess with healthcare then they could possibly develop a broad following by sheer brute force against that issue; that's a key for them.  Will they do it and if so what will they replace healthcare law with?  No; there's too much money in the game for Repubs to solidify together in such a fasion.  Healthcare law can be good for them if they show a better alternative and solidify behind upsurping the current system.  It's no longer about rich and poor more, solidarity; cause everyone wants to be part of a positive cause and that's where the voters are!

The GOP is smart politically.  You have to hand them that.  They know that their base in in rural areas and keep the farm subsidies flowing even as they cut budgets for benefits that flow to urban areas mainly.  There's a method to the populist madness.

Republican supporters hardly need celebrate. If they look carefully at the past few election cycles, they may notice a pattern. GoP majorities correlate with legislative stasis. Claims of making government smaller only appear more ludicrous as they increase the money spent on the military and on subsidizing their monetary backers. Look carefully and you will see that among the largest recipients of federal aid are the red states. So much for reducing the size of government and cutting spending. Cutting taxes? Whose? How do you think they will continue to support their states and interests if they really cut taxes? We already know that the tax code benefits the absurdly wealthy - so the average working joe is not going to benefit from voting GoP.

The GoP has been drifting further right and is already in the region of being a group defined by color, race and financial status. The fact that voters did not question what the GoP really intends to do, policy by specific policy, should worry every single GoP supporter. You will get what you voted for - but are you sure you really wanted it? It's too late now, but think about it anyway....
Though I agree with you in general, this President had a democratic controlled House and Senate his first two years. So the democratic party is also partially responsible for Obama's difficulties.

And they passed the Affordable Care Act.

Geez, what did you expect?
Congress? No it is the people not making things happen with their voyes to extend the adversarial stance of the Congress. Congress has no power the people didn't give them.

Congress has been an impediment to Obama these past six years, and now he is going to have to deal with them for another two? I feel bad for the guy...would not be fun to have a job when none of your ideas can passed because the people you work with are doing whatever they can to be an obstruction. On top of it, he will get blamed for every down turn, when in reality, Congress is the one that is not making things happen.

Oh, but if only we could! You are so correct.
Have you see the ACA map? Or any other socio-economic/policy adoptive map? Republicans somehow still manage to get people of low socio-economic status to vote against their own economic interests. Those persons make use of the advantages offered to them by Democratic initiatives but yet they vote to support candidates and initiatives that would repeal those new found benefits. Benefits which these voters now hold so dear.

I will never forget the "Keep your government hands off my Medicare" sign held aloft in my state of birth and residence. The one and (thank goodness) the only, SC.

It is amazing, isn't it, how Republicans have that base and they keep it stoked and they show up for them at election time.  So they have the money and the voters, whereas the Dems only have the money.  What the Dems need is a base of people who are actually committed to voting and not those we see here in the NY Times comments who are only too happy to stay home when the election happens because they think their party will be punished but not them.
You're admitting Obama's speech was bogus?

Now it's the Democrats' turn to blame the GOP for not getting anything done. And I just sent Obama a case of Pilot pens from OfficeMax to veto all of the bogus bills the GOP think they are going to pass.
Maybe the Democrats should shut down the government next year -- it seemed to work for the GOP last year.
What comes around goes around.
Maybe we can have a Democrat congressman shout "You Lie!" the next time Boehner or McConnel give a bogus speech to the Congress.
We can put this shoe on the other foot -- the GOP makes it pretty clear what to do: "my way or the highway" -- and "hell no we won't" and "the guardians of gridlock."
And we can now blame it all on the GOP -- after all they are now the ones running the government right?

I'm sorry but some bills deserved to be left to "rot"> When they are anti women, anti gay, anti environment, cutting taxes on the rich to benefit a few and bankrupt the rest, prayer in schools etc ect. It's not the number, it's the quality. These were tea party show bills. They haven't put up any serious legislation.
I can't believe you bought that party line....sounds like you're still with them to me?!
It seems choosing not vote is a right of citizenship in the United States of America ... and a statement.  What it means?  Stay tuned.

This means only 1/6 of our population still believe in this democracy. I cannot believe it when I read who is holding the funding against ebola. I guess not many Republicans volunteered in Africa and ebola can never touch them.
"He (Obama) called on Congress to quickly pass an emergency request for funding to combat Ebola, and announced that he would seek congressional authorization for his military campaign in Iraq and Syria."
How does conflating eligible voters with the entire population not indirectly add up to the claim that 17 year olds don't believe in democracy, Optimist?

Only 36.6% of eligible voters voted [source: U.S. News and World Report]. The Republicans, winning a slim majority represent a tad over 1/6 of the "American People" How is this representative government?
he's been washed up for a few years now....  certainly NOT worth the money even if he was clean!!!

Enough already with the anti-A-Rod snarky rants!
I am a lifelong Yankee fan and I can't wait to see if he can do a decent job at third and at the plate next year.
I'm so done with the self-righteous nattering about PEDs.
Test, suspend as appropirate----and play ball!!
True that. The Panda doesn't take PEDs unless they're in the filling of a jelly doughnut...but he's an October stud, unlike the third baseman referenced here...
And the San Francisco Giants are still the 2014 World Series champions!  Ha! Ha!
Right on, Bob. The Yankees can afford to pay off bums like A-Rod.
Now Republicans will actually achieve something positive, rather than constantly whining and blocking action.  If they don't, adios.
